mentions.context: SecAgg also introduces challenges for other defense methods.
PySyft decouples private data from model training, using federated learning, differential privacy, and multi-party computation (MPC) within PyTorch.

MATCHA [469] further improves the performance of PD-SGD by randomly sampling clients for computation and communication, and provides a convergence analysis showing that local updates can accelerate convergence.
• PySyft [399] is a Python library for secure, private Deep Learning.
• PyVertical [32] is a project focusing on federated learning with data partitioned by features (also referred to as vertical partitioning) in the cross-silo setting; see Section 2.2.
While SecAgg is designed to be robust to significant numbers of dropouts [81], there is still the potential for failure.
In short, SecAgg is a tool used to ensure that the server only sees an aggregate of the client updates, not any individual client updates.

These include TensorFlow Federated [38], Federated AI Technology Enabler [33], PySyft [399], Leaf [35], PaddleFL [36] and Clara Training Framework [125]; more details in Appendix A. Commercial data platforms incorporating federated learning are in development from established technology companies as well as smaller start-ups.
Platforms like TensorFlow Federated [38] welcome the contribution of new datasets and may be able to provide hosting support.

Note that while TensorFlow Federated is listed under "Software for simulation", its design includes abstractions for aggregation and broadcast, and serialization of all TensorFlow computations for execution in non-Python environments, making it suitable for use as a component in a production system.
The open source package TensorFlow Federated [38] supports loading decentralized dataset in a simulated environment with each client id corresponding to a TensorFlow Dataset Object.

Wang et al. [469] propose MATCHA, a decentralized SGD method based on matching decomposition sampling, that reduces the communication delay per iteration for any given node topology while maintaining the same error convergence speed.
• PySyft [399] is a Python library for secure, private Deep Learning.
While useful for ensuring privacy, SecAgg generally makes defenses against adversarial attacks more difficult to implement, as the central server only sees the aggregate of the client updates.

This would require a Python interpreter with TensorFlow backend, which may not be a feasible choice for end-user devices due to resource constraints (binary size, memory use), performance limitations, or security concerns.
For instance, Google's FL system [81] relies on TensorFlow for both server and device side execution as well as model and parameter transfer, but this choice suffers from several shortcomings:

A Software and Datasets for Federated Learning • TensorFlow Federated [38] specifically targets research use cases, providing large-scale simulation capabilities as well as flexible orchestration for the control of sampling.

• The intermediate representation GraphDef used by TensorFlow is not standardized or stable, and version skew between the frontend and older on-device backends causes frequent compatibility challenges.
More speculatively, it may be possible to perform versions of SecAgg that aggregate over multiple computation rounds.

Another possibility would be to develop an asynchronous version of SecAgg that does not require clients to participate during a fixed window of time, possibly by adapting techniques from general asynchronous secure multi-party distributed computation protocols [430].
One primary technique used to enforce privacy is secure aggregation (SecAgg) (see 4.2.1).
Recent work has found ways to approximate the geometric median under SecAgg [379] by using a handful of SecAgg calls in a more general aggregation loop.
• It offers no easy path to devices for alternative front ends such as PyTorch [370], JAX [86] or CNTK [410].

The main roadblocks to the applicability of PIR have been the following: cPIR has high computational cost [423], while the non-colluding parties setting has been difficult to achieve convincingly in industrial scenarios.
It has also been used in federated settings for spam classifier training by Snap [378].

MPC approaches to PIR break down into two main categories: computational PIR (cPIR), in which a single party can execute the entire server side of the protocol [286], and information theoretic PIR (itPIR), in which multiple non-colluding parties are required to execute the server side of the protocol [121].

These include TensorFlow Federated [38], Federated AI Technology Enabler [33], PySyft [399], Leaf [35], PaddleFL [36] and Clara Training Framework [125]; more details in Appendix A. Commercial data platforms incorporating federated learning are in development from established technology companies as well as smaller start-ups.
However, there is no single manner in which to incorporate these techniques into FedAvg. SCAFFOLD [265] models the difference in client updates using control variates to perform variance reduction.
This reduces the window of time during which client dropouts would adversely affect SecAgg.
However, it is not clear in general which aggregators can be computed under the use of SecAgg.
One extreme form of a representation is the original high-level description, e.g. a Python TensorFlow program [2].
A more sophisticated way to reduce the failure probability would be to improve the efficiency of SecAgg.
2. Broadcast: The selected clients download the current model weights and a training program (e.g. a TensorFlow graph [2]) from the server.
One extreme form of a representation is the original high-level description, e.g. a Python TensorFlow program [2].

Bulletproofs [92]) can guarantee that the DP-based clipping defense described above is compatible with SecAgg, but developing computationand communication-efficient range proofs is still an active research direction.
Recent work has found ways to approximate the geometric median under SecAgg [379] by using a handful of SecAgg calls in a more general aggregation loop.
Unfortunately, unresponsive clients become more challenging to contend with when using secure aggregation (SecAgg) [80,58], especially if the clients drop out during the SecAgg protocol.
A similar scheme is used by Xie et al. [485] to design a variant of local SGD in which clients locally perform Adagrad [335,161].

While Google has pioneered cross-device FL, interest in this setting is now much broader, for example: Apple is using cross-device FL in iOS 13 [25], for applications like the QuickType keyboard and the vocal classifier for "Hey Siri" [26]; doc.ai is developing cross-device FL solutions for medical research [149], and Snips has explored cross-device FL for hotword detection [298].
PySyft decouples private data from model training, using federated learning, differential privacy, and multi-party computation (MPC) within PyTorch.

Most existing SNARK constructions leverage quadratic arithmetic programs [196,369,136] and are now available in open-source libraries, such as libsnark [307], and deployed in cryptocurrencies, such as Zcash [62].
Recently, Karimireddy et al. [264] proposed a general approach for adapting centralized optimization algorithms to the heterogeneous federated setting (MIME framework and algorithms).
Google makes extensive use of federated learning in the Gboard mobile keyboard [376,222,491,112,383], as well as in features on Pixel phones [14] and in Android Messages [439].
The open source package TensorFlow Federated [38] supports loading decentralized dataset in a simulated environment with each client id corresponding to a TensorFlow Dataset Object.
Split learning also enables matching client-side model components with the best server-side model components for automating model selection as shown in the ExpertMatcher [413].

Note that while TensorFlow Federated is listed under "Software for simulation", its design includes abstractions for aggregation and broadcast, and serialization of all TensorFlow computations for execution in non-Python environments, making it suitable for use as a component in a production system.
Unfortunately, unresponsive clients become more challenging to contend with when using secure aggregation (SecAgg) [80,58], especially if the clients drop out during the SecAgg protocol.
The computational cost can be traded for more communication; we refer the reader to Ali et al. [16] to better understand the communication and computation trade-offs offered by cPIR.

Most existing SNARK constructions leverage quadratic arithmetic programs [196,369,136] and are now available in open-source libraries, such as libsnark [307], and deployed in cryptocurrencies, such as Zcash [62].

Note that while TensorFlow Federated is listed under "Software for simulation", its design includes abstractions for aggregation and broadcast, and serialization of all TensorFlow computations for execution in non-Python environments, making it suitable for use as a component in a production system.
